title: Baumann, D. 2011. The Physics of Inflation (Lecture notes), Chapter 2

cells.data:
## 2.1 Motivation

> How [do] quantum fluctuations in quasi-de Sitter space produce a spectrum of fluctuations that accurately matches the observations[?]

Why inflation _inevitably_ produces fluctuations: $\phi(t)$ governs the energy density $\rho(t)$, playing the role of a local clock reading off “the amount of inflation remaining”; quantum-mechanical clocks have fluctuations:
\begin{align}
\delta \phi(t,\mathbf{x}) = \phi(t,\mathbf{x}) - \bar{\phi}(t)
\end{align}

**Different regions of space inflate by different amounts**
* $\Rightarrow$ inflation ends at different times, $\delta t(\mathbf{x})$
* $\Rightarrow$ local curvatures will be different
* $\Rightarrow$ local densities will be different

## 2.3 Quantum origins of cosmological perturbations

### 2.3.1 Canonical quantization

Promote $v$ and $a_\mathbf{k}^\pm$ to operators (denoted by $\hat{}$):

\begin{align}
\hat{v}(\tau,\mathbf{x}) = \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^3\mathbf{k}}{(2\pi)^{3/2}} \Big[ \hat{a}_\mathbf{k}^- v_k(\tau) e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot\mathbf{x}} + \hat{a}_\mathbf{k}^+ v_k^*(\tau) e^{-i\mathbf{k}\cdot\mathbf{x}} \Big]
\end{align} $\hat{a}_\mathbf{k}^\pm$ are now creation and annihilation operators.

### 2.3.2 Non-uniqueness of the vacuum

Can always define a second annihilation operator such that $\hat{b}_\mathbf{k}^- \left|0\right\rangle_b = 0$, where $\left|0\right\rangle_b \neq \left|0\right\rangle_a$.

### 2.3.3 Choice of the physical vacuum

In **time-independent** spacetime (Minkowski), choose the definition of $v$ that minimizes the vacuum expecation energy $_v\!\left\langle 0 \right| \hat{H} \left|0\right\rangle_v$:
\begin{align}
v_k(\tau) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2k}} e^{-ik\tau}.
\end{align}

In **time-dependent** spacetimes, trickier because for the $v_k(\tau_0)$ that minimizes $\langle\hat{H}\rangle$ at time $\tau_0$, $v_k(\tau_1)$ does **not** necessarily also minimize $\langle\hat{H}\rangle$ at time $\tau_1$.

At sufficiently early times, $k/aH \sim \!\left|k\tau\right| \gg 1$ (subhorizon), so that
\begin{align}
\omega_k^2 = k^2 - \frac{2}{\tau^2} \rightarrow k^2
\end{align} is time-independent (i.e., unaffected by gravity) and
\begin{align}
v_k'' + k^2 v_k = 0.
\end{align} The only “minimal excitation state” solution is $v_k \propto e^{-ik\tau} \Rightarrow$ **All modes have time-independent frequencies at sufficiently early times.** Choose the initial condition
\begin{align}
\lim_{\tau\rightarrow -\infty} v_k(\tau) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2k}} e^{-ik\tau}.
\end{align}
> This defines a preferable set of mode functions [$v_k$] and a unique physical vacuum [$\left|0\right\rangle_v$], the _Bunch–Davies vacuum_.

### 2.3.4 Zero-point fluctuations in de Sitter

The M–S equation in de Sitter space has the exact solution
\begin{align}
v_k(\tau) = \alpha \frac{e^{-ik\tau}}{\sqrt{2k}} \bigg(1-\frac{i}{k\tau}\bigg) + \beta \frac{e^{ik\tau}}{\sqrt{2k}} \bigg(1+\frac{i}{k\tau}\bigg).
\end{align} The Bunch–Davies vacuum as the initial condition sets $\alpha = 1, \beta = 0$:
\begin{align}
v_k(\tau) &= \frac{e^{-ik\tau}}{\sqrt{2k}} \bigg(1-\frac{i}{k\tau}\bigg) \\
\Rightarrow \lim_{k\tau \rightarrow 0} v_k(\tau) &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\cdot\frac{-i}{k^{3/2}\tau} \\
\Leftrightarrow \lim_{k\ll aH} v_k(\tau) &= a^{-1/2}\left(\frac{2k}{a}\right)^{-1/2} \frac{iaH}{k},
\end{align} which is different from Peacock’s result by a factor $a^{-1}$ (minus sign went away because $\tau < 0$).

This leads to a power
\begin{align}
P_v = v_k v_k^* = \frac{(aH)^2}{2k^3}.
\end{align} Since $\zeta = v/z$ while $z^2 = a^2 \dot{\phi}^2/H^2 = 2a^2\varepsilon$,
\begin{align}
P_\zeta = \frac{1}{z^2}P_v = \frac{H^4}{2k^3\dot{\phi}^2} = \frac{H^2}{4k^3\varepsilon}.
\end{align}

## 2.4 Curvature perturbations from inflation

$z^2 = 2a^2 \varepsilon \equiv 0$ in pure de Sitter space, so $\zeta = v/z$ is ill-defined.

$\varepsilon$ describes deviation from de Sitter $\rightarrow$ inflation ends.

### 2.4.1 Results for quasi-de Sitter

$\zeta$ freezes at horizon crossing, so evaluate $P_\zeta$ at $k = aH$:
\begin{align}
P_\zeta(k) &= \left.\frac{H^2}{4k^3 \varepsilon} \right|_{k=aH} \\
\Rightarrow\quad \Delta_s^2(k) &= \frac{k^3}{2\pi^2} P_\zeta(k) = \left. \frac{H^2}{8\pi^2\varepsilon} \right|_{k=aH}
\end{align} in non-dimensionalized form. **Where does the $2\pi^2$ come from?** It makes $\Delta_s^2$ equivalent to Peacock’s $\delta_H^2$ though. Maybe $4\pi k^2 \mathrm{d}k/(2\pi)^3$ like in Peacock?

**Why does $\zeta$ freeze at horizon crossing? We just showed the $k\ll aH$ limit, right?**
I think it’s because $\zeta$ was shown to be time-independent on superhorizon scales – _I think that was also for the $k\ll aH$ limit_. Maybe some sort of symmetry argument regarding horizon exit and re-entry?

If $H$ and $\varepsilon$ are time-independent, then $\Delta_s^2(k) = \text{constant} \Rightarrow$ **scale-invariance**; otherwise,
\begin{align}
n_s - 1 = \frac{\mathrm{d}\log \Delta_s^2(k)}{\mathrm{d} \log k} \neq 0 \quad\Leftrightarrow\quad n_s \neq 1
\end{align}

Can show that
\begin{align}
n_s - 1 = -2\varepsilon - \eta.
\end{align} **$n_s$ controlled by $H, \dot{H}, \ddot{H} \rightarrow$ inflation dynamics.**

### 2.4.2 Systematic slow-roll expansion

Can also show the same thing using a systematic expansion in slow-roll parameters (i.e., first-order effects).
